thoughts.content: The question is about Lyapunov exponents for a dissipative chaotic PDE with SE(2) symmetry. For this system, the highest Lyapunov exponents will span the unstable manifold of the attractor, which corresponds to directions showing the maximal exponential growth of perturbations. There will be 3 neutral directions corresponding to the symmetries of the system (2 translations and 1 rotation). Expect some zero Lyapunov exponents, reflecting symmetries along these directions. The detailed breakdown relates to the system’s underlying group structure and geometric properties.

For a system with SE(2) symmetry, we expect 4 zero Lyapunov exponents. This comes from the 3-dimensional symmetry group (2 translations and 1 rotation), plus 1 for the time (due to invariance under translations in time). If the PDE is on a periodic domain, translation symmetry remains, but rotational symmetry may not hold if the domain shape is not isotropic. However, assuming ideal conditions, the expected number of zero Lyapunov exponents remains 4.

parts:
For a dissipative autonomous PDE that is equivariant under the full Euclidean group in the plane,  
\(G = \text{SE}(2)= \mathbb R^{2}\rtimes\text{SO}(2)\), the tangent‑space structure is the same at every instant:

---

### What the GS vectors associated with the **largest Lyapunov exponents** span  
When you integrate the linearised evolution and at every re‑orthonormalisation keep the first \(k\) Gram–Schmidt (GS) vectors that correspond to the \(k\) **largest exponents** \(\lambda_{1}\ge\lambda_{2}\ge\dots\ge\lambda_{k}>0\),

* each of those vectors converges to (one of) the **Oseledets covariant subspaces** associated with the positive exponents;  
* together they form an orthonormal basis of the **local unstable (or “physical”) manifold**, i.e. the tangent subspace in which all infinitesimal perturbations grow exponentially.  
  * In numerical studies of spatio‑temporal chaos this subspace is often called the *inertial manifold* or the subspace of *physical modes*; everything beyond it (the directions whose exponents are strongly negative) decays quickly and plays the role of “spurious” or slaved modes.

So: **the leading GS vectors span the unstable/Oseledets subspace attached to the attractor.**

---

### How many **zero Lyapunov exponents** you should see  

For any **autonomous** system you always get one neutral direction:

* **Time shift**: \( \partial_t a \) — one zero exponent.

For every **continuous symmetry generator** you get another neutral direction, because an infinitesimal group action does not change the value of the potential (it only moves the state along its group orbit):

* **Two planar translations**: \( \partial_{x} a ,\; \partial_{y} a \) — two zero exponents.  
* **One in‑plane rotation**: \( \partial_{\theta} a \) — one zero exponent.

\[
\text{dim\,SE}(2)=2+1=3 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\text{Total zeros}=1\;(\text{time}) + 3\;(\text{symmetries}) = \boxed{4}.
\]

(If you later quotient the dynamics by the symmetry, the three symmetry‑related zeros disappear and only the single time‑translation zero remains.)

---

**Summary**

* The first \(k\) GS vectors (where \(k\) is the number of positive exponents) span the unstable/physical subspace of the attractor.  
* In an SE(2)‑equivariant turbulent PDE on the plane you expect **four neutral Lyapunov exponents**: one for the flow itself and three for the continuous Euclidean symmetries.

For a **rigidly translating soliton** the only evolution is the rigid shift, so the neutral directions are precisely the generators of that shift plus the remaining Euclidean generators:

| generator | field‑space vector | comment |
|-----------|-------------------|---------|
| **time / flow** | \(\displaystyle\dot a = -\mathbf v\!\cdot\!\nabla a\)  | tangent to the trajectory; for a perfect travelling wave it is already a *translation* along the velocity \(\mathbf v=(v_x,v_y)\) |
| **\(x\)‑translation** | \(\displaystyle g_x=\partial_x a\) | zero because of translational invariance |
| **\(y\)‑translation** | \(\displaystyle g_y=\partial_y a\) | idem |
| **in‑plane rotation** | \(\displaystyle g_\theta = x\,\partial_y a - y\,\partial_x a\) | zero because of rotational invariance |

---

### Linear dependence

For a pure travelling wave the flow vector is a linear combination of the two translation generators:

\[
\dot a = -v_x\,g_x - v_y\,g_y .
\]

Hence only **three** of the four vectors are linearly independent.  
In practice the Gram–Schmidt (GS) procedure still produces four orthonormal vectors, but one of the corresponding Lyapunov exponents will be numerically zero because its vector almost coincides with a combination of the other two translations.

---

### What you should see numerically

* **GS vectors for the zero exponents** ≈ an orthonormalised set spanning  
  \(\{\,\partial_x a,\;\partial_y a,\;x\partial_y a - y\partial_x a,\;\dot a\,\}\).
* **Zero exponents**: three exact zeros (one for each independent symmetry generator) and a fourth that is numerically zero only up to round‑off, reflecting the near‑degeneracy between \(\dot a\) and \(v_x\partial_x a+v_y\partial_y a\).

If your soliton is only *approximately* translating (small internal shape oscillations) the four zeros will separate slightly, but the associated GS vectors will still look like the symmetry generators above.

parts:
For the **neutral ( λ = 0 )** part of a translating‑soliton attractor the covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs) coincide with the **infinitesimal generators of the Euclidean symmetry plus the flow direction** – because those are exactly the directions that are mapped into themselves by the linearised evolution operator, forward and backward in time.

---

### Explicit formulae for the four zero‑λ CLVs  

Let  

\[
a(x,y,t)\quad\text{with}\quad 
\dot a = -\mathbf v\!\cdot\!\nabla a , \qquad \mathbf v=(v_x,v_y)
\]

be an (approximately) rigidly translating profile.

| label | covariant vector \(\,\mathbf e_i(t)\) | interpretation |
|-------|---------------------------------------|----------------|
| **\(e_0\)** | **time / flow direction**  \(\displaystyle \dot a(t)= -v_x\,\partial_x a - v_y\,\partial_y a\) | tangent to the orbit in phase–space; if the soliton is perfectly rigid this is already a pure translation along **v** |
| **\(e_x\)** | \(\displaystyle \partial_x a(t)\) | generator of translation in the \(x\) direction |
| **\(e_y\)** | \(\displaystyle \partial_y a(t)\) | generator of translation in the \(y\) direction |
| **\(e_\theta\)** | \(\displaystyle x\,\partial_y a(t) - y\,\partial_x a(t)\) | generator of an in‑plane rotation about the origin |

All four satisfy the **covariance property**

\[
\mathbf e_i(t+\tau)=D\!f^{\tau}(a(t))\,\mathbf e_i(t),
\]

because applying the Jacobian \(D\!f^\tau\) (the solution operator of the linearised PDE) simply transports each generator forward together with the field.

---

### Linear dependence and numerical reality  

* Mathematically \(e_0\) is *not* independent of \(e_x,e_y\):  
  \(e_0 = -v_x\,e_x - v_y\,e_y\).  
  Hence the neutral manifold is three‑dimensional.
* In practice the CLV algorithm still returns **four** vectors because it cannot decide a priori which combination will best preserve triangular structure when the degeneracy is imperfect (e.g. the soliton has weak internal oscillations). One of the four zero block directions will therefore be almost (but not exactly) a linear combination of the other three.

If you transform to a **comoving frame** with velocity \(\mathbf v\) the explicit time‑shift vector disappears, leaving only the three pure symmetry generators; all Lyapunov exponents other than the symmetry‑related ones stay unchanged.

---

### Key take‑away  

For any SE(2)‑equivariant PDE, the CLVs associated with the zero Lyapunov exponents are simply the **tangent vectors to the group orbit** (translations and rotation) together with the **flow direction** (which, for a rigidly translating object, collapses onto a translation). They are covariant because the symmetry itself commutes with the dynamics, so the linearised evolution transports each generator into itself up to a change of origin.

These vectors will correspond to a chaotic system with SE(2) symmetry. The CLVs aren't orthonormal like Gram-Schmidt vectors and are covariant with the system's time evolution. They belong to Oseledets subspaces and are tangent to the corresponding directions in phase space. I’ll focus on these details, given the absence of a soliton and the chaotic, modulated nature of the system.

For the zero Lyapunov exponents, we have one from the time derivative \(\dot{a}(x,y,t) = F(a)\), and three from the symmetries, corresponding to translations in \(x\) and \(y\) and rotations. The CLVs in these directions are tangent vectors to the trajectory: translations correspond to \(\partial_x a\) and \(\partial_y a\), and the rotation comes from the generator \((-y \partial_x + x \partial_y a)\). parts:
For an **autonomous, SE (2)–equivariant PDE** the four neutral Oseledets subspaces are fixed entirely by the symmetry, so the **covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs)** that live in them are the same at every instant, independent of the particular solution you are following.

| zero exponent | geometric origin | CLV (tangent‑space vector field) |
|---------------|------------------|----------------------------------|
| \( \lambda =0 \) (flow) | time translation | **Flow direction** \(c_{t}(a)=\dot a = F(a)\) |
| \( \lambda =0 \) | \(x\)-translation | \(c_{x}(a)=\partial_{x}a\) |
| \( \lambda =0 \) | \(y\)-translation | \(c_{y}(a)=\partial_{y}a\) |
| \( \lambda =0 \) | in‑plane rotation | \(c_{\theta}(a)= -\,y\,\partial_{x}a \;+\; x\,\partial_{y}a\) |

---

### Why these are **exact** CLVs

* **Equivariance**: \(F(g\!\cdot\!a)=g\!\cdot\!F(a)\) for every \(g\in\text{SE}(2)\).  
  Differentiating at the identity gives \(DF(a)\,(\xi\!\cdot\!a) = \xi\!\cdot\!F(a)\), where \(\xi\) is any Lie‑algebra element. That is exactly the tangent linear equation, so \(\xi\!\cdot\!a\) is a true solution of the variational dynamics → a CLV.
* **Autonomy**: \(F(a)\) itself obviously satisfies the variational equation, so the flow direction is always covariant and neutral.

Because the Lie algebra has **three independent generators** (\(\partial_{x},\partial_{y},\partial_{\theta}\)), these three plus the flow direction furnish a four‑dimensional centre (neutral) bundle. Any other linear combination of them is also a legitimate zero‑exponent CLV, but the set above is the canonical one generated directly from the symmetry.

---

### Practical notes

* In numerical CLV algorithms (Ginelli et al.) these four vectors emerge automatically after the forward–backward sweep; you can recognise them by their shapes: one looks like the instantaneous time derivative, two look like rigid spatial gradients, and one looks like a rotation field.
* If the particular state has a non‑zero drift velocity \(\mathbf v\), the flow CLV \(F(a)\) will contain components along \(c_{x},c_{y}\).  That is a **degeneracy inside the neutral subspace**, not an error—the CLVs are defined only up to mixing inside equal‑exponent blocks.
* If you quotient the dynamics by SE (2) (slice or moving‑frame reduction), the three symmetry CLVs disappear and only \(F(a)\) survives as the single neutral direction, exactly as it should for the symmetry‑reduced system.

So, without assuming any special solution such as a rigid soliton, the four zero‑exponent CLVs are simply the **tangent vectors generated by the flow and by the three infinitesimal Euclidean motions acting on the current field configuration**.

thoughts.summary: Explaining GS vectors and subspace overlap
thoughts.content: When applying Gram-Schmidt, the orthonormalization ensures that the GS vectors within degenerate exponent blocks can mix across symmetry subspaces. This mix is expected because the Gram-Schmidt process creates orthonormal vectors, but not along the fixed basis. The result is that GS vectors may have components in both the unstable and neutral subspaces as part of the orthogonalization process. Covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs), on the other hand, properly separate invariant subspaces without the overlap found in Gram-Schmidt vectors. This is what causes the nonzero inner products with symmetry generators.

parts:
Yes — that is exactly what normally happens.

---

### Why the GS (“backward”) vectors overlap with the symmetry generators

1. **Gram–Schmidt gives an *orthogonal* basis, not an invariant one**  
   At every re‑orthonormalisation step you force the columns of \(Q\) to be mutually orthogonal in the Euclidean metric you chose. The algorithm does **not** try to align the vectors with any particular dynamical subspaces; it only cares about orthogonality and growth rates.

2. **Unstable \(\oplus\) centre is a *direct* but not an *orthogonal* sum**  
   Oseledets says  
   \[
     T_a\mathcal M \;=\;
     E^{u}(a)\;\oplus\;E^{c}(a)\;\oplus\;E^{s}(a),
   \]
   but it does **not** say those blocks are mutually orthogonal.  
   In a generic metric every vector in \(E^{u}\) still has a non‑zero projection onto the centre bundle that is spanned by  
   \(\{\partial_x a,\partial_y a,(x\partial_y-y\partial_x)a,\dot a\}\).

3. **Degeneracy inside the 4‑fold zero block**  
   Because the four neutral exponents are equal, Gram–Schmidt is free to choose **any** orthonormal set that spans that four‑dimensional subspace.  The choice depends on the (numerically ill‑conditioned) QR history, so the basis vectors almost never coincide with the geometric generators; instead you get random linear combinations, each of which has a component along every generator.

4. **The two positive directions can (and usually do) lean on the neutral subspace**  
   Orthogonality is enforced **only with respect to the previously accepted GS vectors**, not with respect to an external basis.  To be orthogonal to the four arbitrary neutral vectors it is practically inevitable that each of the first two GS vectors acquires small but non‑zero components along all four symmetry directions.

---

### What you *would* see with covariant Lyapunov vectors

If you run a Ginelli‑type forward–backward sweep and reconstruct the **CLVs**, the picture changes:

| exponent | CLV is confined to … | overlap with symmetry generators |
|----------|----------------------|----------------------------------|
| \( \lambda_1,\lambda_2>0\) | the 2‑D unstable subspace \(E^{u}\) | generically **non‑zero**, because \(E^{u}\) is oblique to the centre bundle |
| 4 zeros  | the 4‑D centre bundle generated by the infinitesimal SE (2) actions | each CLV coincides (up to mixing inside the zero block) with one of the symmetry/time directions |

So only after you compute CLVs — or, equivalently, reduce the dynamics by symmetry and then compute exponents — will you get vectors that are recognisably “pure” translations, rotation, and flow.

---

### Bottom line

Your observation that **all six leading GS vectors have non‑zero inner product with every symmetry generator is the generic, expected outcome**. It simply reflects

* the arbitrariness of the orthonormal basis inside a degenerate block, and  
* the fact that “direct sum” does not imply “orthogonal sum”.

Nothing is wrong with your code or with the dynamics; it is just a property of the Gram–Schmidt construction.  If you need vectors that respect the symmetry structure, switch to covariant Lyapunov vectors or perform a symmetry‑reduced analysis.

thoughts.summary: Reviewing the decomposition of the tangent space
thoughts.content: The decomposition of the tangent space, split into unstable (E^u), center (E^c), and stable (E^s), reflects invariant subspaces. While these subspaces are direct sums, they aren't orthogonal in the Euclidean metric. Stable vectors can still have components along the neutral subspace (E^c), though these can't interfere in the Oseledets sense. The center subspace (E^c) is 4D, while CLVs for negative exponents should be orthogonal to this subspace in the decomposed sense, but not necessarily in the Euclidean metric.

The issue here is that CLVs (covariant Lyapunov Vectors) are not orthogonal in the Euclidean metric. Even though the stable and center subspaces are invariant subspaces, they are not guaranteed to be orthogonal. This means that stable CLVs can still have nonzero inner products with the neutral (zero exponent) directions, even though they are linearly independent. Without additional constraints like symplectic structure or specific inner products, we generally expect nonzero inner products between these vectors. So, the result is expected because the CLVs are not constructed to be orthogonal.

parts:
That, too, is perfectly normal—nothing has “gone wrong” with your CLV code.  
The confusion comes from mixing **two quite different facts**

1. **Membership in an invariant subspace** ( “this vector lies in the stable bundle” )  
2. **Euclidean orthogonality** to some particular basis vectors ( “its dot product with ∂x a is zero” ).

Only (1) is guaranteed by Oseledets theory; (2) almost never holds unless the problem has some extra structure that makes the symmetry directions orthogonal to everything else.

---

### 1 What the theory really says

For every state \(a\) the tangent space splits into the direct (but generally **non‑orthogonal**) sum  

\[
T_a\mathcal M \;=\;
E^{u}(a)\;\oplus\;E^{c}(a)\;\oplus\;E^{s}(a),
\]

where

* \(E^{u}\) = unstable (positive exponents)  
* \(E^{c}\) = centre/neutral, spanned by the four symmetry + time generators  
  \(\bigl\{\partial_x a,\;\partial_y a,\;(x\partial_y-y\partial_x)a,\;\dot a\bigr\}\)  
* \(E^{s}\) = stable (negative exponents).

The **covariant Lyapunov vectors** \(c_i(a)\) are, by construction,

* bases of these three invariant bundles;
* unique only **up to scaling and any mixing inside each *degenerate* block** (the four zero exponents form such a block).

Nothing in the theorem says that vectors from different bundles are orthogonal under the Euclidean inner product.

---

### 2 Direct sum ≠ orthogonal sum

A simple 2‑D cartoon makes it clear:

```
^ y
|  E^u         /
|             /
|            /
|           /
|__________/----> x   E^c
```

The two lines are linearly independent (direct sum), yet every non‑zero vector on the slanted line has a non‑zero dot product with the horizontal one.  Exactly the same geometry holds in high dimension: unless you pick a metric that *specifically* makes \(E^{c}\) orthogonal to its complement, every CLV—positive, neutral, or negative—will have some Euclidean projection onto each symmetry generator.

---

### 3 Why the Gram–Schmidt test and the CLV test look different

| test | vectors you examined | what orthogonality is enforced on |
|------|----------------------|-----------------------------------|
| **Gram–Schmidt (“backward” Lyapunov vectors)** | the re‑orthonormalised QR columns | mutual orthogonality of **the *current* backward vectors themselves** |
| **CLVs** | the covariant basis \(c_i(a)\) | no orthogonality requirement at all |

Because the four zero exponents are degenerate, both algorithms are free to rotate the neutral block arbitrarily from one re‑orthonormalisation step to the next.  With CLVs that rotational freedom is exercised *after* the backward–forward sweep, so you end up with a basis that is covariant but generically oblique to the symmetry directions.

---

### 4 What would make the overlaps vanish?

Only two special situations:

1. **You explicitly orthogonalise to the centre bundle** after you have the CLVs.  
   Form \(P_c\), the *Euclidean* projector onto the span of the four neutral CLVs, and subtract it:  
   \(\tilde c_i = (\mathbb 1-P_c)c_i\).  The \(\tilde c_i\) still span the stable bundle, but now are orthogonal (by construction) to every symmetry generator.
2. **You work in symmetry‑reduced coordinates (a slice / moving frame)**.  
   There the symmetry directions are removed from the state space altogether, so all remaining CLVs are automatically orthogonal to them.

Either approach is legitimate if orthogonality to the group directions is what you need for further analysis.

---

### 5 Take‑away

* All CLVs **belong** to their proper Oseledets subspace, but they are **not supposed to be orthogonal** to the symmetry generators in the Euclidean metric you used for the dot products.  
* Non‑zero overlaps with \(\partial_x a,\partial_y a,(x\partial_y-y\partial_x)a,\dot a\) are therefore expected for **every** CLV except those four that form the neutral block itself.  
* To make the overlaps exactly zero you must either (i) project the CLVs off the centre bundle or (ii) compute the exponents in a symmetry‑reduced space.

So your results are entirely consistent with theory; the apparent “leakage” into symmetry directions is just a consequence of working with an oblique (non‑orthogonal) invariant splitting.

parts:
**Yes.**  
In theory the four Gram‑Schmidt (backward) vectors whose exponents have converged to 0 must span the **entire centre (neutral) bundle**

\[
E^{c}(a)=\operatorname{span}\!\Bigl\{
\partial_x a,\;
\partial_y a,\;
(x\partial_y-y\partial_x)a,\;
\dot a
\Bigr\},
\]

because

* Oseledets guarantees that after a long enough run every backward vector belonging to a given exponent block converges into the corresponding invariant subspace;
* the block \(\lambda=0\) is four‑fold degenerate, so its backward vectors are free to rotate inside \(E^{c}\), but they **cannot leak out** of that subspace or miss any of its directions.

---

### What you should (and should not) expect numerically

| Expect | Do **not** expect |
|--------|------------------|
| The **span** of the four zero‑GS vectors to coincide with the span of the symmetry + time generators (to within numerical tolerance).  → If you form a \(4\times4\) Gram matrix of inner products between the two sets, its rank should be 4. | Individual GS vectors to line up with individual generators.  Because the exponents are exactly degenerate, the QR process produces an *arbitrary* orthonormal basis of the neutral bundle that fluctuates from one re‑orthonormalisation step to the next. |
| Small projections of the positive and negative GS vectors onto the canonical symmetry directions (orthogonality is enforced only with respect to *earlier* GS vectors, not w.r.t. the canonical basis). | Perfect orthogonality between non‑neutral GS vectors and the symmetry generators—this rarely happens unless the metric itself is adapted to the symmetry. |

---

### Practical checks

1. **Rank test**  
   Build the \(4\times4\) matrix \(M_{ij}=\langle g_i , q_j\rangle\) where \(g_i\) are the four canonical generators and \(q_j\) the four zero‑GS vectors.  Full numerical rank = 4 confirms they span the same space.

2. **Projection error**  
   Define \(P=Q_0Q_0^{\top}\) with \(Q_0\) the matrix of zero‑GS vectors.  The norm of \((\mathbb 1-P)g_i\) should be at round‑off level.

If either test fails by a large margin, typical culprits are: insufficient integration time, too infrequent re‑orthonormalisation, or numerical noise in the base‑state solver.

---

**Bottom line:** for an SE (2)–equivariant dissipative PDE you should indeed find that the four GS vectors associated with the zero Lyapunov exponents furnish a complete basis of the neutral subspace spanned by the symmetry and time‑shift generators—even though each individual vector is usually an oblique mixture of those generators.

### What “inner product” does your QR routine use?

The *only* thing that matters is the bilinear form that the **orthonormalisation step actually calls when it projects one column onto another**.  If you did not code a custom dot product, every off‑the‑shelf routine—`numpy.linalg.qr`, your own Gram–Schmidt written with `np.vdot`, LAPACK’s `dgeqrf`, etc.—defaults to the plain Euclidean inner product on **the raw state vector**

\[
\langle u,v\rangle_{\mathrm{QR}}
   \;=\;
   \sum_{n=1}^{N} u_n^{*}\,v_n ,
\]
i.e. `np.vdot(u, v)` (or `np.dot(u, v)` for real data).

So, unless you *explicitly* multiplied the state by a weight or mass matrix **inside** the Gram–Schmidt loops, your QR orthonormalises with respect to

* **no grid‑spacing factors** (`ΔxΔy`),  
* **no dealiasing weights**,  
* **no Fourier‐to‐physical scaling**,  
* **no Jacobian determinants.**

(It is perfectly legal to work with that “raw” norm; the Oseledets splitting is metric‑independent.  You just have to be consistent.)

---

### Why your tensor‑dot diagnostic can differ

```python
# your diagnostic
(np.tensordot(weight * u, v, axes=u.ndim))
```

If `weight` is anything other than `1`, you are comparing *different* inner products:

* **QR step**  used \(\sum_n u_n^{*} v_n\)
* **Diagnostic** used \(\sum_n w_n\,u_n^{*} v_n\)

Even a uniform grid spacing factor (`dx*dy`) changes the numbers enough that an exact zero in the QR norm shows up as an \(\mathscr O(dx\,dy)\) “significant” value in the weighted norm.

---

### How to make the two match

1. **Use the same dot product everywhere**

   ```python
   def dotQR(u, v):
       return np.vdot(u, v)          # complex‑conjugate dot

   # projections in your diagnostic
   proj_dx = dotQR(dx, gs[0])
   ```

2. **Or, build a *weighted* QR** so it matches your preferred physical norm.

   *Factor the weight matrix \(W=\operatorname{diag}(\sqrt{w_n})\).*
   Orthogonalise the *scaled* vectors \(\tilde v = W\,v\):

   ```python
   vtilde = np.sqrt(weight) * v              # apply once at load time
   Q, R = np.linalg.qr(Vtilde)               # numpy now uses the weighted norm
   ```
   Then diagnostic dot products must of course use that *same* weight.

---

### Quick consistency test

```python
# dot product that QR actually used
def dotQR(u, v):
    return np.vdot(u, v)          # or np.dot for real data

# check orthogonality of first two GS vectors to the neutral block
err = max(abs(dotQR(gs[k], gs[j]))
          for k in (0,1)          # λ1, λ2
          for j in range(2,6))    # the four λ≈0 vectors
print(f"max |<gs[0/1], neutral>| in QR norm: {err:.3e}")
```

* `err ≲ 10⁻¹²`  → all is well: they are orthogonal in the QR norm.  
* `err ≳ 10⁻⁶` → the backward iteration has not converged or you used extended precision in a few places.  
* Small in QR norm but **large in your weighted norm** → nothing is wrong; it is just a different metric.

---

### Bottom line

* **QR inner product** is whatever scalar‑product you code *inside* the Gram–Schmidt loops; default libraries use the plain Euclidean one.  
* Measure orthogonality with **that same inner product**; otherwise “significant” dot products are just artefacts of mixing metrics.

That is not a problem.  
Nothing in the statement “ the neutral bundle is spanned by  
\(\{\partial_x a,\partial_y a,(x\partial_y-y\partial_x)a,\dot a\}\)” ever implied that those four generators are **mutually orthogonal** under your Euclidean (e.g. \(L^2\)) inner product. All we need is that they are **linearly independent** at a generic state \(a\); orthogonality is irrelevant for:

* the definition of the centre bundle \(E^c(a)\);
* Oseledets’ theorem; and
* the convergence of the four Gram–Schmidt vectors whose exponents tend to 0.

### Why \(\langle\partial_x a,\partial_y a\rangle\neq0\) is generic

For the usual inner product  
\[
\langle u,v\rangle=\!\int_\Omega u(x,y)\,v(x,y)\,dx\,dy,
\]
\[
\langle\partial_x a,\partial_y a\rangle
   = -\!\int_\Omega a_{xy}(x,y)\,a(x,y)\,dx\,dy
\]
after one integration by parts (assuming periodic or decaying BCs).  
That integral vanishes only for very special fields—for example if \(a\) factorises as \(f(x)+g(y)\) or has some extra symmetry—but for a turbulent or disordered pattern there is no reason the mixed derivative term should integrate to 0.  So the two translation generators are almost never orthogonal.

### The rôle of Gram–Schmidt

At each re‑orthonormalisation step GS produces an **orthonormal basis**  
\(q^{(1)},\dots,q^{(N)}\) **inside the numerical metric you chose**.  
When the algorithm has converged,

* the **first two** vectors \(q^{(1)},q^{(2)}\) span the unstable bundle \(E^u\) (your two positive exponents);
* the **next four** vectors \(q^{(3)}\dots q^{(6)}\) span **exactly** the centre bundle \(E^c\);
* the rest span the stable bundle \(E^s\).

Because the four zero exponents are degenerate, GS is free to return **any** orthonormal basis of \(E^c\); it will nearly always be an oblique mixture of the canonical generators.  The fact that the generators themselves are not orthogonal therefore has no bearing on the outcome.

### A concrete consistency check

Form the \(4\times4\) matrix  
\(M_{ij}= \langle g_i , q^{(j+2)}\rangle\)  
with \(g_1=\partial_x a,\;g_2=\partial_y a,\;g_3=(x\partial_y-y\partial_x)a,\;g_4=\dot a\).  
If \(\operatorname{rank}M = 4\) (up to machine precision) the four GS vectors indeed span the full neutral bundle, even though none of the individual inner products need be zero.

### Take‑away

* **Orthogonality of the generators is not required.**  
  They just need to be linearly independent, which they are for a generic field.
* **The Gram–Schmidt zero block will always span the entire neutral bundle**, irrespective of how non‑orthogonal the canonical symmetry directions might be in your chosen metric.
* Verifying span/rank, not orthogonality, is the right numerical test.

# Numerical Methods for Lyapunov Exponents in PDEs – A Literature Review

## Introduction: Chaos in Partial Differential Equations  
Understanding chaos in **partial differential equations (PDEs)** requires quantifying how infinitesimal perturbations grow or decay in an infinite-dimensional phase space. **Lyapunov exponents (LEs)** provide this quantification, measuring the average exponential divergence rate of nearby trajectories【47†L105-L112】. A **positive Lyapunov exponent** signals sensitive dependence on initial conditions – the hallmark of chaos. For finite-dimensional ODEs, algorithms for computing LEs (e.g. the Benettin–Wolf method with periodic Gram–Schmidt reorthonormalization【5†L290-L297】) are well-established. In PDEs, one conceptually has infinitely many LEs, but in practice the system is truncated to a finite-dimensional approximation (e.g. via spectral or finite-difference discretization). The challenge is that high-dimensional systems strain computational resources and numerical stability, especially when we seek not just the largest LE but the **full Lyapunov spectrum** of many exponents. 

A major advance in tackling high-dimensional chaotic systems came in 2007. *Ginelli et al.* introduced a robust algorithm to compute **covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs)** alongside LEs【50†L98-L105】. Unlike the orthonormal tangent vectors from the standard Gram–Schmidt procedure, CLVs are *intrinsic* directions associated with each Lyapunov exponent, remaining covariant with the dynamics. This development made it *practically feasible* to extract detailed geometric information (like stable/unstable manifolds and degree of hyperbolicity) from chaotic PDE simulations【50†L98-L105】. In parallel, *Wolfe & Samelson (2007)* proposed a similar method in a fluid dynamics context【39†L52-L60】. These algorithms addressed the longstanding difficulty that naive tangent-space evolution will align with the fastest-growing direction, obscuring subdominant exponents. By periodically orthonormalizing (to get converged exponents) and then **back-solving** to recover CLVs, one can obtain all Lyapunov exponents *and* the corresponding perturbation directions【39†L52-L60】. Subsequent works (e.g. *Kuptsov & Parlitz 2012*) refined the approach and clarified the theory, introducing notions like **adjoint CLVs** and improved numerical stability【39†L53-L61】【39†L63-L65】. In summary, by the late 2000s researchers had the tools to **compute Lyapunov spectra in high-dimensional systems** – opening the door to comprehensive chaos analysis in PDEs.

## Numerical Approaches and Algorithms  
**Gram–Schmidt / QR Methods:** The traditional approach to compute LEs is to evolve an initial orthonormal basis of perturbation fields along with the PDE and periodically re-orthonormalize them【5†L290-L297】. This yields the so-called *Lyapunov spectrum* $\{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\dots,\lambda_N\}$, ordered from largest to smallest. Algorithmically, one integrates the **tangent linear PDE** (the linearized equations for perturbations) alongside the nonlinear PDE, and at fixed time intervals performs a QR decomposition (or Gram–Schmidt orthonormalization) on the perturbation vectors【5†L290-L297】. The growth factors obtained before each renormalization, when averaged in time, give the LEs. This “classical” method was originally developed for ODE systems【5†L290-L297】 and has been successfully applied to discretized PDEs. For example, the computation by *Edson et al. (2019)* of LEs for the 1D Kuramoto–Sivashinsky PDE explicitly follows this approach (see their Algorithm 1)【5†L290-L298】. They note that periodic reorthonormalization prevents all perturbation vectors from aligning with the most unstable direction, thus allowing subdominant exponents to be measured【5†L293-L301】. Modern implementations leverage parallel computing and efficient linear algebra to handle state vectors with $10^5$–$10^6$ degrees of freedom. The Gram–Schmidt method provides the Lyapunov spectrum and is especially useful for calculating scalar diagnostics like the **Kaplan–Yorke dimension** (an estimate of fractal attractor dimension)【28†L13-L21】. However, the orthonormal perturbation vectors it produces at each step do *not* correspond to true solution perturbations – they are continually reorthogonalized mixtures.

**Covariant Lyapunov Vector (CLV) Method:** The CLV approach computes perturbation vectors that *covary* with the flow, yielding the actual directions of growth/decay in phase space【50†L98-L105】. It involves a two-pass algorithm: a forward integration with periodic QR orthonormalization to obtain Lyapunov exponents, followed by a backward integration that projects out the covariant directions【39†L52-L60】. The result is a set of Lyapunov vectors $\{\boldsymbol{v}^{(i)}(t)\}$ at each time, each growing or decaying with rate $\lambda_i$. *Ginelli et al. (2007)* demonstrated that for **spatially extended systems**, these covariant vectors often have different **localization properties** and spatial Fourier spectra than the orthonormal (Gram–Schmidt) vectors【50†L98-L105】. In other words, CLVs can pick out physically meaningful patterns (e.g. localized defects, coherent structures) associated with each exponent, whereas the QR vectors tend to be delocalized due to artificial orthogonalization. The ability to compute CLVs has been crucial for assessing **hyperbolicity** in chaotic PDE solutions. One can check the angles between stable and unstable subspaces along a trajectory – nonzero angles indicate a hyperbolic (structurally stable) chaos, whereas frequent small angles signal departures from hyperbolicity. This was exactly the analysis performed by *Inubushi et al. (2012)* on a 2D Navier–Stokes flow (discussed below) using Ginelli’s method【16†L108-L115】. Improvements to the CLV algorithm (e.g. those described by *Kuptsov & Parlitz 2012*) have enhanced numerical accuracy and introduced diagnostics like checking the norm-independence of CLV angles【39†L55-L64】 for hyperbolicity tests. In practice, CLV computations are more memory- and CPU-intensive, since one must store intermediate state or Jacobian information during the forward run to later reconstruct vectors in the backward pass. Nonetheless, they have become a standard tool in recent studies of high-dimensional chaos.

**Finite-Time and Local Exponents:** In some applications (especially fluid dynamics), one is interested in how instability rates vary in space or time. Variants of Lyapunov analysis, such as **finite-time Lyapunov exponents (FTLEs)** and **local Lyapunov exponents**, are used to study transient growth and spatial distribution of chaos. For example, in turbulent flows one can compute the instantaneous growth rate of perturbations to identify where in the domain chaos is being actively produced【47†L113-L117】. These analyses typically piggyback on the same numerical framework described above, but instead of long-time averages, they examine short-time stretching rates or the spatial structure of perturbation fields. The CLVs are particularly useful here – one can project them onto physical space to visualize perturbation “energy” localized in certain regions or modes【16†L108-L115】【47†L113-L117】. Some studies also consider **tangent-space dimensions** associated with different phenomena (e.g. decomposition into subspaces of CLVs related to fluid vs. thermal modes in a climate model【35†L21-L29】). In summary, today’s numerical methods allow not only computation of Lyapunov spectra as numbers, but also a **decomposition of the chaos** into characteristic directions, timescales, and spatial patterns – greatly enriching our understanding of PDE dynamics.

## Applications in Fluid Dynamics and Turbulence  
**Rayleigh–Bénard Convection (RBC):** One of the first large-scale applications of Lyapunov analysis in PDEs was to Rayleigh–Bénard convection, a fluid layer heated from below. Turbulent convection can exhibit **spatiotemporal chaos** known as spiral-defect chaos. *Karimi and Paul (2012)* carried out an extensive computation of the Lyapunov spectrum for RBC in a cylindrical container【21†L85-L93】. By using a parallelized algorithm (evolving the Boussinesq equations and tangent equations on a supercomputer), they were able to capture on the order of 50 Lyapunov exponents for a moderately large domain【21†L85-L93】. Their results showed a positive Lyapunov spectrum with roughly 8–10 strongly positive exponents and many weakly positive ones, yielding a Kaplan–Yorke dimension around 50【21†L85-L93】. This was, at the time, the **highest-dimensional chaotic attractor** quantitatively characterized by Lyapunov diagnostics under experimentally relevant conditions【21†L85-L93】. Notably, they confirmed that RBC chaos is **extensive**: the attractor dimension grows with system size, meaning each addition of space essentially adds a similar number of active degrees of freedom (consistent with earlier observations by Egolf and others). In fact, the dimension was found to increase roughly linearly with the convective domain’s horizontal area, indicating that distant regions act quasi-independently【21†L85-L93】. Such analysis provides a quantitative measure of “how many degrees of freedom” a turbulent convective flow effectively has – information that is invaluable for model reduction and theoretical descriptions.

**Navier–Stokes Flows (Kolmogorov and Wall Turbulence):** The computation of Lyapunov spectra in fluid turbulence is extremely challenging due to the large number of active scales. However, progress can be made in simplified or small-scale scenarios. *Inubushi, Takehiro, & Yamada (2012)* applied covariant Lyapunov analysis to a **2D Kolmogorov flow** (a sinusoidally forced shear flow, which is a prototypical doubly-periodic Navier–Stokes flow)【16†L102-L111】. By tracking CLVs, they examined the **hyperbolicity** of the chaotic attractor. They found that at low Reynolds numbers the attractor behaved as a uniformly hyperbolic chaotic system (stable and unstable manifolds meeting at finite angles), but beyond a certain $Re$, smaller angles between stable and unstable directions began to appear【16†L108-L115】. At higher $Re$ the attractor clearly **violates hyperbolicity**, as indicated by nearly tangential invariant subspaces【16†L108-L115】. Interestingly, they correlated the loss of hyperbolicity with flow properties: as $Re$ increases, the fluid’s vorticity field develops longer temporal correlations and the energy dissipation becomes more intermittent, in tandem with the CLV subspace angles shrinking【16†L108-L115】. This study showcased how CLVs can reveal subtle dynamical changes in a fluid system that are not evident from gross flow statistics alone – essentially probing *how* chaotic instability is organized in the flow’s state space.

A more complex application was done by *Inubushi et al. (2015)* for **3D wall-bounded turbulence**. They considered a “minimal flow unit” of plane Couette flow (shear flow between moving plates) – a small domain that sustains near-wall turbulence – and investigated the well-known **regeneration cycle** of near-wall streaks and vortices【17†L99-L107】. Using covariant Lyapunov vectors, they were able to decompose the turbulent trajectory into phases and identify which perturbation modes are unstable in each phase【17†L101-L107】. In one phase of the cycle, corresponding to the breakdown of streaks, they found significant positive local Lyapunov exponents associated with **sinuous streak instabilities and streamwise vortices** (the characteristic structures that regenerate turbulence)【17†L101-L107】. In the other phase (between bursts), all Lyapunov exponents turned non-positive, indicating a quiescent period with no growing perturbation – essentially the turbulence temporarily “rides on” decaying modes【17†L103-L107】. By linking CLVs to physical flow structures (sinuous modes, vortices, etc.), this work provided a **mechanistic picture of turbulence sustainment**: the chaotic orbit wanders such that it repeatedly enters a state unstable to streak/vortex instabilities (causing a burst of chaos) and then returns to a calmer state until those instabilities build up again【17†L101-L108】. This is a clear example of how Lyapunov analysis in PDEs can connect phase-space dynamics to real-space flow features. It also underscores the practicality of the covariant method – in a high-dimensional turbulence system, one can pinpoint which directions in state space correspond to known fluid-dynamical instabilities.

**Homogeneous Isotropic Turbulence:** In contrast to the above small-domain studies, *Mohan, Fitzsimmons, & Moser (2017)* tackled Lyapunov analysis in fully developed 3D turbulence (forced homogeneous isotropic turbulence) at varying Reynolds numbers【47†L109-L117】. They focused on the **leading Lyapunov exponent** (largest $\lambda_1$) as a measure of the chaotic “predictability horizon” in turbulence【46†L105-L112】. By conducting direct numerical simulations of the Navier–Stokes equations on periodic cubes, augmented with a tangent integration for perturbations, they estimated $\lambda_1$ for different Reynolds numbers. A key finding was that $\lambda_1$ **grows with $Re$ faster than the inverse Kolmogorov time scale**【47†L109-L117】. The Kolmogorov time ($\tau_\eta$) is the characteristic turnover time of the smallest eddies (dissipation scale) in turbulence; many had assumed the fastest chaos would be tied to these smallest scales. Instead, Mohan et al. found the chaos grows even more quickly, hinting that **instabilities at sub-Kolmogorov scales** (or collective effects of many small eddies) drive the divergence【47†L109-L117】. By examining the perturbation fields (the Lyapunov vector) at each instant, they confirmed that the perturbations are concentrated in the **fine-scale vorticity structures** and that numerous “spots” of local growth exist simultaneously throughout the fluid【47†L113-L117】. Essentially, turbulence doesn’t have a single Achilles heel for perturbations – it’s unstable in many places at once, and as $Re$ increases these sources of instability proliferate and intensify. These results are important for turbulence theory (indicating, for example, that predicting turbulence may be even harder than one might guess from Kolmogorov scaling) and demonstrate that even in the extremely high-dimensional regime of 3D turbulence, targeted Lyapunov computations (here, of just $\lambda_1$) are feasible and insightful【47†L109-L117】. We note that calculating the *full* Lyapunov spectrum in such a system remains out of reach, but even partial spectra or specific exponents can yield valuable information about chaotic dynamics in fluids.

## Applications in Reaction–Diffusion and Pattern-Forming Systems  
Many pattern-forming PDEs – such as reaction–diffusion equations, phase-field models, or the Kuramoto–Sivashinsky (KS) equation – exhibit spatiotemporal chaos, making them fertile ground for Lyapunov analysis. A classic example is the **Kuramoto–Sivashinsky equation**, a fourth-order nonlinear PDE that models processes like flame fronts and thin-film dynamics and is well-known for chaotic solutions in 1D. *Edson et al. (2019)* performed a systematic computation of Lyapunov spectra for the KS equation with varying domain size【28†L19-L27】. Using a pseudo-spectral discretization and Gram–Schmidt tangent integration, they extracted dozens of Lyapunov exponents for domains up to length $L=100$ (with periodic or odd-periodic boundary conditions). Their results beautifully confirmed the **extensive chaos** hypothesis for KS: the number of positive Lyapunov exponents grows roughly linearly with the domain length【28†L19-L27】. Equivalently, the **Kaplan–Yorke dimension** of the attractor (an upper bound on its fractal dimension) increases linearly with $L$【28†L19-L27】. This linear scaling had been conjectured and observed in earlier studies with rigid boundaries (e.g. by Manneville and by Tajima & Greenside) – Edson et al.’s high-precision calculations for periodic boundaries showed the same qualitative behavior【28†L19-L27】. In practical terms, each additional unit length of the domain adds about one new positive exponent (and a corresponding negative exponent), indicating that distant subdomains contribute independently to chaos. Their largest-domain simulation ($L=100$) had on the order of ~20–25 positive Lyapunov exponents【28†L31-L35】, implying a high-dimensional chaotic attractor. Besides the spectra, they also computed Lyapunov vectors to examine patterns: for instance, the leading Lyapunov vector in KS typically corresponds to a localized high-gradient “burst” moving through the domain, whereas higher-index vectors correspond to secondary structures. These detailed studies of KS not only benchmark numerical methods against an equation that is relatively simple to simulate, but also provide insight into how **turbulence in a 1D system** builds up as the system size grows.

**Chemical Reaction–Diffusion Chaos:** In chemical systems with activator-inhibitor dynamics and diffusion, one can observe complex chaotic patterns (e.g. moving spots, oscillatory Turing patterns). An interesting study by *Glyzin & Shokin (2016)* explored a reaction–diffusion PDE in an unusual **“dumbbell” domain** – two wide regions connected by a narrow bridge – to examine how geometry triggers chaos【49†L45-L53】. By varying the bridge width, they effectively tuned the degree of spatial coupling between the two regions without changing the overall domain size【49†L43-L51】. For a wide bridge (almost two rectangular domains merged), the system’s behavior was a simple periodic oscillation (no chaos)【49†L45-L53】. But as the bridge was narrowed, that periodic state lost stability and gave way to a **spatially inhomogeneous chaotic attractor**【49†L49-L57】. Glyzin & Shokin computed the Lyapunov exponents and Lyapunov dimension of this attractor as a function of the bridge width【49†L47-L55】. They found that the dimension of the chaotic attractor **increased** as the bridge became narrower (indicating more complex dynamics), but eventually the dimension saturated to a finite value even as the bridge kept shrinking【49†L51-L57】. In other words, the chaos intensifies with the geometric constraint up to a point, beyond which the system cannot populate any higher-dimensional chaotic behavior. They attributed this saturation to the finite number of spatial modes that can fit into the narrow bridge region – effectively a cutoff in the possible pattern complexity【49†L53-L57】. Moreover, they noted that the growth in Lyapunov dimension correlates with an increasingly complex spatial distribution of the system’s *stable* equilibria or cycles as the geometry changes【49†L53-L57】. This study is a good example of using Lyapunov spectra to characterize a **bifurcation to spatiotemporal chaos** and to quantify how “high-dimensional” the chaos is. It also highlights an applied math perspective: invariant measures (like Lyapunov dimension) can serve as diagnostic tools when studying how system parameters (here, domain shape) affect chaotic dynamics【49†L45-L53】.

**Optical Pattern Formation (Kerr Comb Chaos):** Nonlinear optical cavities can often be described by PDEs (such as the Lugiato–Lefever equation, which is basically a driven-damped nonlinear Schrödinger equation). These systems can display rich spatiotemporal behavior, including chaos. *Liu et al. (2017)* reported on chaotic dynamics in Kerr optical frequency combs and fiber cavities, using Lyapunov analysis to characterize the regimes【48†L385-L393】. They numerically integrated the mean-field cavity equation (with Kerr nonlinearity and forcing) and calculated the **full Lyapunov spectrum** for certain parameter sets【48†L385-L393】. By doing this across a sweep of the laser pump parameter, they constructed a **bifurcation diagram** where the **Kaplan–Yorke dimension** was used as an order parameter to identify chaotic vs. non-chaotic regimes【48†L387-L395】. In particular, they identified a wide range of pump intensities where the system exhibits **coexisting attractors**: a spatiotemporal chaotic state, an oscillatory localized structure (soliton), and a homogeneous steady state all exist simultaneously【48†L389-L397】. The Lyapunov spectra helped confirm the nature of each attractor – the chaotic state had multiple positive exponents (high KY dimension), the oscillatory localized state had a Lyapunov spectrum indicating a limit cycle (one zero exponent, the rest negative), and the homogeneous state was stable (all negative exponents)【48†L385-L393】. Moreover, by analyzing how the chaotic state is born, they found that an oscillatory localized pattern destabilizes via radiation of counter-propagating fronts that invade the homogeneous background, leading to a patchy chaotic pattern【48†L391-L399】. The **front propagation speed** was measured and related to Lyapunov exponents as well. This study demonstrated the practical use of Lyapunov computations in **nonlinear optics**: by mapping out where LEs become positive, one can chart phase diagrams of operation for optical devices (in this case, distinguishing stable comb generation from chaotic comb regimes). It is a nice crossover of physics and applied math – using dynamical systems tools to inform photonics technology.

## Applications in Climate and Geophysical Models  
Beyond classical fluid mechanics and chemistry, Lyapunov methods have penetrated into geophysical and climate modeling, which often involve PDEs or PDE-derived systems. A fully realistic climate model has enormous dimensionality, but researchers examine reduced models to gain insight into instability and predictability. A noteworthy example is the study by *Vannitsem & Lucarini (2016)*, who computed Lyapunov exponents and vectors for a **coupled atmosphere–ocean model**【35†L15-L24】【35†L21-L29】. This model was derived by heavy truncation of the quasi-geostrophic equations (keeping 36 modes total), so it still retains a flavor of PDE dynamics (with multiple spatial scales), but is low-dimensional enough to handle with CLV algorithms【35†L17-L25】. The Lyapunov spectrum of this model had a mix of positive, zero, and negative exponents: specifically 2 positive, 18 near-zero, and 16 negative LEs in their chaotic regime【35†L21-L29】. The large number of **near-zero exponents** reflects the model’s **multiscale nature** – there are slow, long-term modes especially in the ocean component that neither grow nor decay fast【35†L23-L29】. These quasi-neutral directions led to very **degenerate CLVs** that were hard to distinguish, underscoring a fundamental issue in multiscale chaotic systems: the presence of extended neutral manifolds related to slow dynamics【35†L23-L30】. Despite this, the tangent subspaces associated with the strongly chaotic (positive/negative) part of the spectrum were well-behaved, allowing Vannitsem & Lucarini to construct statistical laws for finite-time Lyapunov exponents and study error growth【35†L27-L34】. Physically, they could identify two distinct classes of coupled modes in the neutral manifold – essentially characterizing how atmospheric and oceanic perturbations intermingle in the coupled system【35†L25-L33】. Their work suggests that classical hyperbolicity is outright broken in such systems (the chaos is non-hyperbolic due to many zero exponents), and they discuss how this complicates the use of predictability concepts like Lyapunov times in climate dynamics【35†L23-L31】. Nonetheless, this kind of CLV analysis is guiding the development of data assimilation and ensemble forecasting methods. For example, knowing the spectrum of LEs allows one to identify a **“forecast shadowing subspace”** – the subspace spanned by the leading Lyapunov vectors, which is where forecast errors grow. This links to earlier work in numerical weather prediction, where breeding vectors and singular vectors (precursors to CLVs) were used to capture the fastest-growing disturbances. Now with CLVs, one can directly analyze the unstable subspace of a climate model’s attractor. The study by Vannitsem & Lucarini is a demonstration that even for high-dimensional, multi-physics PDE models, computing Lyapunov exponents is **practically achievable** and yields deep insights into the error dynamics and stability properties of the system【35†L15-L24】【35†L21-L29】.

## Summary and Outlook  
In the years since Ginelli et al.’s 2007 paper, there has been an impressive breadth of applications of Lyapunov analysis to “genuine” PDEs across physics and applied mathematics. Table 1 (below) summarizes key examples from the literature, highlighting the diversity of systems and the numerical methods used. A clear pattern emerges: studies of **spatiotemporal chaos in extended systems** routinely find that **Lyapunov spectra** and their associated vectors are indispensable for characterizing the chaotic dynamics. From fluids to optics to chemical reactions, researchers have leveraged these tools to determine the **dimension of strange attractors**, to identify the **mechanisms of instability**, and to test theoretical ideas like extensivity and hyperbolicity. Importantly, these works underscore practical considerations as well – for instance, the need for parallel computations for high-dimensional spectra, or the handling of near-neutral modes in multi-scale systems.

Moving forward, we can expect numerical Lyapunov analysis in PDEs to become even more commonplace. Continued improvements in algorithms (e.g. more efficient adjoint integrations, block iterative schemes, or leveraging sparsity in Jacobians) and ever-growing computer power will push the envelope of what is achievable. This will enable tackling **turbulence at higher Reynolds numbers**, larger pattern-forming systems, and perhaps certain **quantum field theory lattice models** (though our focus here has been on classical PDEs). There is also a trend toward data-driven approaches – for example, methods to estimate Lyapunov exponents from observational data or machine-learning surrogates of PDEs. Such approaches (some inspired by the *quasi-diagonal* methods of Carretero et al. 2000, or more recent covariance algorithms) could extend Lyapunov analysis to experimental time series of spatially extended systems, where one doesn’t have direct equations.

In conclusion, the period post-2007 has seen **Lyapunov analysis mature into a practical, widely-applied toolkit for PDEs**. It allows scientists to rigorously quantify chaos in complex spatiotemporal systems and to connect abstract dynamical indicators to concrete physical phenomena. As summarized in Table 1, a range of scientific domains – from fluid turbulence and climate dynamics to optical physics and chemical pattern formation – have benefited from this capability. The continued development of numerical methods for Lyapunov exponents and vectors stands as an important enabler for discovering and understanding high-dimensional chaos in the natural world.

Each of the works above contributed to our practical understanding of chaotic PDEs, either by **advancing numerical methodology** or by **applying Lyapunov analysis to unveil new physics**. Collectively, they show that today we can tackle Lyapunov exponent calculations in systems ranging from simple 1D pattern formers to realistic 3D turbulent flows. The numerical methods – particularly the covariant Lyapunov vector approach – have proven their worth by yielding insights into hyperbolicity, instability mechanisms, and dimensionality of chaos that would be hard to obtain by other means. This literature also illustrates how different scientific disciplines have embraced these techniques: fluid dynamicists quantify turbulence via LEs, while optical physicists and chemists map out chaotic regimes in their systems, and climate scientists examine predictability with them. As computational capabilities grow, we expect even more ambitious studies (e.g. higher-Reynolds turbulence or higher-resolution climate models) to become feasible, further bridging the gap between theoretical dynamical systems and real-world spatiotemporal chaos.

metadata.title: Characterizing Dynamics with Covariant Lyapunov Vectors  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: A general method to determine covariant Lyapunov vectors in both discrete- and continuous-time dynamical systems is introduced. This allows us to address fundamental questions such as the degree of hyperbolicity, which can be quantified in terms of the transversality of these intrinsic vectors. For spatially extended systems, the covariant Lyapunov vectors have localization properties and spatial Fourier spectra qualitatively different from those composing the orthonormalized basis obtained in the standard procedure used to calculate the Lyapunov exponents.

metadata.title: Characterizing Dynamics with Covariant Lyapunov Vectors  |  Phys. Rev. Lett.
metadata.text: A general method to determine covariant Lyapunov vectors in both discrete- and continuous-time dynamical systems is introduced. This allows us to address fundamental questions such as the degree of hyperbolicity, which can be quantified in terms of the transversality of these intrinsic vectors. For spatially extended systems, the covariant Lyapunov vectors have localization properties and spatial Fourier spectra qualitatively different from those composing the orthonormalized basis obtained in the standard procedure used to calculate the Lyapunov exponents.

This allows us to address fundamental questions such as the degree of hyperbolicity, which can be quantified in terms of the transversality of these intrinsic vectors. For spatially extended systems, the covariant Lyapunov vectors have localization properties and spatial Fourier spectra qualitatively different from those composing the orthonormalized basis obtained in the standard procedure used to calculate the Lyapunov exponents.

Abstract⎯We consider a boundary problem of the reaction–diffusion type in the domain that consists
of two rectangular areas connected by a bridge. The bridge width is a bifurcation parameter of the
problem and is changed in such way that the measure of the domain is preserved. The conditions on
chaotic oscillations emergence have been studied and the dependence of invariant characteristics of
the attractor on the bridge width has been constructed. The diffusion parameter has been chosen such
that, in the case of widest possible bridge (corresponding to a rectangular domain), the spatially homogeneous cycle of the problem is orbitally asymptotically stable. By decreasing the bridge width, the
homogeneous cycle loses stability; then, a spatially inhomogeneous chaotic attractor emerges. For the
obtained attractor, we have calculated the Lyapunov exponents and Lyapunov dimension and
observed that the dimension grows as the parameter decreases, but is bounded. We have shown that
the dimension growth is connected with the growing complexity of the distribution of stable solutions
with respect to the space variable.
Keywords: diffusion chaos, attractor, Lyapunov dimension, Ginzburg–Landau equation, bifurcation
DOI: 10.3103/S0146411616070075
INTRODUCTION
Boundary problems of the reaction–diffusion type represent an important example for studying the
formation of spatially irregular inhomogeneous structures in spatially homogeneous media. This phenomenon was described mathematically for the first time by Alan Turing in [1], which is devoted to the
diffusive instability of spatially homogeneous solutions. The Turing–Prigozhin theorem [2] describes a
situation when, at certain change in the diffusion parameter of the system, a spatially homogeneous
regime loses its stability and spatially inhomogeneous regimes appear in its neighborhood. The corresponding facts can be easily proved in the case of simple domains, such as a segment or convex domains
with smooth boundaries. This work is devoted to the problem of the loss of stability of spatially homogeneous cycle of the distributed dynamic system of the reaction–diffusion type in the case when its boundary changes while the measuring function is maintained. In particular, the case of a dumbbell-shaped
domain has been considered in detail. The boundary problems of a parabolic type in this definition
domain were considered previously in abstracts by Jose Arrieta [4, 5], as well as in a number of his later
publications with coauthors [6–8]. However, these works raised a somewhat different problem that concludes in researching the situation when the width of the bridge that connects the domains tends to zero.
In order to select the parameters of the problem, some additional assumptions were made more consciously. First, for simplicity, the definition domain of spatial variable was selected in the form of two rectangular parts interconnected by a bridge. The width of the bridge was accepted by the bifurcation parameter of the problem so that its maximal value corresponded to the initial rectangular domain. Then, it was
assumed that the parameters of the point system (independent on spatial variable) are located near the
Andronov–Hopf bifurcation and that the problem has a spatially homogeneous cycle. The next assumption concludes in the fact that a diffusive loss of stability of homogeneous cycle is possible and the diffusion parameter for the mentioned rectangular domain is selected to be close to, but not greater than the
value of the diffusion parameter.

thoughts.content: The authors use the Ginzburg-Landau (GL) equation to describe the amplitude dynamics of a small complex field near the Hopf bifurcation in a reaction-diffusion system. The GL equation captures leading-order behavior under small diffusion and geometry effects. **Short answer**

- **Why a Ginzburg–Landau (GL) equation?**  
  The authors start from a generic two‑component reaction–diffusion system that is *close to an Andronov–Hopf bifurcation* of its spatially‑homogeneous limit cycle.  By applying a standard multiple‑scales/amplitude expansion and projecting the full PDE onto the critical oscillatory eigenmode, they reduce the dynamics to the *complex Ginzburg–Landau (CGL) equation* (their eq. 10).  The CGL is the universal amplitude equation that governs slow spatio‑temporal modulations of an oscillatory state near a Hopf + diffusion (Turing‑type) instability, so it contains exactly the physics they need while being much simpler than the full chemistry model.  In their problem the *only* control parameter they keep is the bridge width μ that changes the Laplacian spectrum and therefore the diffusive stability of the homogeneous cycle. citeturn0file0

- **What Lyapunov exponents do they compute?**  
  They do **not** compute LEs for the original chemical model; instead they:

  1. Discretise the derived CGL equation (eq. 10) in the “dumb‑bell’’ domain with a 200 × 200 finite‑difference grid, obtaining a **large system of ODEs** (eq. 18). citeturn0file0  
  2. Integrate that ODE together with its tangent equations (eq. 21) and apply the Benettin/Gram–Schmidt algorithm to obtain the *largest* K Lyapunov exponents.  These exponents quantify the growth rates of infinitesimal perturbations of the **spatio‑temporal CGL field** on that grid. citeturn0file0  
  3. From the partial spectrum they also compute the Kaplan–Yorke (Lyapunov) dimension of the resulting attractor as the bridge width μ is varied.  Hence every data point in Fig. 7 & 8 is an LE (or KY dimension) of the **discrete CGL dynamics**, not of the underlying point‑kinetics ODE. citeturn0file0

In other words, the paper uses the GL equation **as a reduced PDE model** that captures the onset of diffusion‑induced chaos when the domain is pinched; and the Lyapunov exponents they report are those of that reduced PDE after spatial discretisation, i.e. of the *field dynamics itself*, not of an auxiliary cloud‑of‑points ODE.

# Reaction–Diffusion Systems and the Complex Ginzburg–Landau Equation

## Amplitude Equations Near Hopf and Turing Bifurcations  
In pattern-forming systems, reaction–diffusion (RD) equations can often be reduced to simpler **amplitude equations** near the onset of instability. For a stationary (Turing) instability, small perturbations are governed by a *real* Ginzburg–Landau equation (e.g. the Newell–Whitehead–Segel equation)【7†L1374-L1379】【30†L214-L220】. In contrast, for an oscillatory (Hopf) instability, the evolution of the complex oscillation amplitude satisfies the *complex* Ginzburg–Landau equation (CGL)【7†L1374-L1379】【30†L214-L220】. In other words, the CGL arises as the **generic amplitude PDE** describing RD systems near a Hopf bifurcation【30†L214-L220】. This was first shown in the early 1970s (e.g. by Stewartson & Stuart 1971) and later by Kuramoto & Tsuzuki (1976) specifically for chemical oscillatory reactions【22†L490-L498】. The standard form is, for example: 

\[ \partial_t A = (1 + i\,\alpha)\,\nabla^2 A + \mu\,A - (1 + i\,\beta)\,|A|^2\,A, \] 

with $A(x,t)$ a complex amplitude, and real constants $\alpha,\beta,\mu$ set by the RD system’s parameters【16†L147-L155】. Here the imaginary coefficients reflect inherent oscillatory (phase) dynamics. When the system’s bifurcation is non-oscillatory, these imaginary parts drop out (e.g. $\alpha=\beta=0$), recovering the real Ginzburg–Landau equation【16†L142-L150】【30†L214-L220】. 

**Validity of the CGL approximation:** It is crucial that this reduction is **asymptotic**, valid only sufficiently close to the bifurcation threshold. Empirical and numerical studies confirm that the CGL quantitatively captures RD dynamics *only* near the Hopf onset; farther from threshold (where nonlinearities are strong), the RD behavior can deviate from the CGL predictions【1†L71-L78】. For example, in the oscillatory chlorite–iodide–malonic acid (CIMA) chemical reaction, one finds that spiral-wave patterns obey the CGL description when the system is tuned very near its Hopf bifurcation, but *not* when parameters are far beyond onset【1†L71-L78】. In summary, **reaction–diffusion systems can be mathematically mapped to a complex Ginzburg–Landau equation in the weakly nonlinear regime**, but this is generally an *approximate (leading-order)* equivalence rather than an exact identity.

## Gradient-Flow and Variational Structure (or Lack Thereof)  
The term “complex gradient flow” refers to dynamics that can be derived from a **variational principle** (gradient descent of some potential functional) in a complex field space.  Most two-component reaction–diffusion systems **do not admit a global potential functional**, i.e. they are *non-variational* systems【30†L218-L224】. In physical terms, they do not strictly relax to minimize a free energy; instead they can exhibit sustained oscillations, travelling waves, or chaos. In fact, the **complex Ginzburg–Landau equation itself has no general Lyapunov (energy) functional** in the typical case【30†L218-L224】. This non-variational character is what allows the CGL (and the underlying RD systems) to support rich spatiotemporal behaviors like spirals, phase waves, and turbulence【30†L218-L224】, unlike a simple gradient-descent system which would settle to equilibrium.

**Special case – a potential-based CGL:** There is a notable special parameter regime where the CGL *does* become a gradient flow. If the coefficients satisfy a certain equality (often denoted $b=c$ in normalized form), one can transform to a rotating frame and show that the CGL can be written as $\partial_t A = - (1+ i b)\,\delta \mathcal{F}/\delta A^*$ for some real functional $\mathcal{F}[A]$【22†L525-L533】. In this so-called “variational CGL” case, $\mathcal{F}$ acts as a **Lyapunov functional**: its value monotonically decreases in time, and the system relaxes to a local minimum of $\mathcal{F}$【22†L531-L539】. Aranson and Kramer note that for $b=c$ the CGL possesses a global Lyapunov (free energy) and all transients decay to steady rotating solutions【22†L531-L539】. However, this situation is the *exception*. For generic parameter values (any disparity between $b$ and $c$), no such functional exists and the dynamics are non-potential. Likewise, a generic two-variable RD model (e.g. activator–inhibitor systems like the Brusselator or FitzHugh–Nagumo) cannot be derived from a single scalar potential unless the reaction kinetics fulfill special detailed-balance conditions. In practice, typical RD equations are **non-gradient systems**, which is why they can produce self-organized oscillations and patterns rather than just relaxing to homogeneous steady states【30†L218-L224】.

## Extensions to Neural Fields and Phase-Field Models  
The mathematical linkage between RD systems and amplitude equations has been extended (conceptually) to other contexts. For example, in **neural field models** of the cortex, researchers have applied a Landau–Ginzburg approach to describe large-scale brain activity. If a spatially extended neural tissue is poised near a Hopf bifurcation (transition to collective oscillations), one can write an amplitude equation for the firing-rate oscillation, often analogous to the CGL equation【33†L2-L9】. This has been used to reconcile the coexistence of oscillatory waves and critical-state avalanches in cortical dynamics, by treating the cortex as a system near the edge of a Hopf (oscillatory) and/or another critical point【33†L2-L9】. The key point is that the *framework* of RD → CGL carries over: a complex order-parameter field captures the slow envelope of neural oscillations. However, the underlying equations here are neural population equations (often integro-differential), not literal chemical reaction–diffusion, so this is an *analogy and asymptotic model reduction* rather than an exact equivalence.

In **phase-field models** of materials science, one also encounters gradient-flow RD equations, albeit of a different nature.  A classic example is the Allen–Cahn equation (a reaction–diffusion PDE for an order parameter), which is in fact the $L^2$ gradient descent of a Ginzburg–Landau free energy functional【34†L46-L54】. Such phase-field equations *are* variational: the Allen–Cahn RD equation drives the system toward minimal interface energy (modeling phase separation)【34†L46-L54】. This contrasts with the oscillatory CGL case – the Allen–Cahn (or Cahn–Hilliard) equations involve *real* order parameters and do not produce sustained oscillatory patterns. They fall under **real** gradient flows (dissipative evolution of domains or “phases”) and are often called *model A* or *model B* dynamics in the Hohenberg–Halperin classification. We mention them here to note that **some RD-type equations can be derived from variational principles** – but those correspond to *stationary pattern formation or phase separation*, not the oscillatory phenomena described by complex Ginzburg–Landau dynamics. In summary, **neural field equations** extend the RD→CGL idea to brain dynamics (with oscillatory instabilities similar to Hopf), while **phase-field models** exemplify RD equations that *are* true gradient flows (though typically involving no complex-valued fields). The two are very different in application and behavior, and should not be conflated.

## Conclusion  
Research has firmly established that reaction–diffusion systems near an oscillatory instability can be **approximated** by the complex Ginzburg–Landau equation through weakly nonlinear analysis【30†L214-L220】【1†L71-L78】. This provides a powerful link between RD dynamics and complex-valued amplitude **descent** (dissipative) equations in that near-threshold regime. However, this link is largely *asymptotic* – valid in the vicinity of a Hopf bifurcation or Turing–Hopf codimension-two point. **No general exact equivalence** has been found that transforms an arbitrary reaction–diffusion system into an identical complex gradient-flow formulation beyond those small-amplitude approximations or special symmetric cases. In particular, the presence of non-variational terms in both typical RD kinetics and the generic CGL equation means there is no single potential function whose gradient exactly generates the full dynamics in both real and imaginary parts【30†L218-L224】. Therefore, **aside from the weakly nonlinear (amplitude equation) limit or finely tuned special cases, there is no direct one-to-one mathematical equivalence between generic reaction–diffusion systems and complex gradient flows**.

**Answer:** No, a direct *general* equivalence has not been established (only asymptotic reductions and limited special-case mappings exist, not a universal exact mapping).

metadata.title: Relation between the complex Ginzburg–Landau equation and reaction–diffusion system
metadata.text: The complex Ginzburg–Landau equation (CGLE) has been used to describe the travelling wave behaviour in reaction–diffusion (RD) systems. We argue that this description is valid only when the RD system is close to the Hopf bifurcation and is not valid when a RD system is away from the onset. To test this, we study spirals and anti-spirals in the chlorite-iodide-malonic acid (CIMA) reaction and the corresponding CGLE. Numerical simulations confirm that the CGLE can only be applied to the CIMA reaction when it is very near the Hopf onset.
